title: 104_hr125
content: The Act may be cited as the "Gun Crime Enforcement and Second Amendment Restoration Act of 1996". The Congress finds that protecting citizens from armed violent criminals is a primary duty of government. Banning specific types of firearms does not deter criminals from acquiring weapons to harm innocent citizens. The most effective way to ensure public safety from gun-related crimes is to focus on enforcement and restoration of the Second Amendment. The most effective way to protect the public from gun-wielding violent criminals is to arrest, convict, and incarcerate such predators, ensuring they serve sufficient sentences to prevent quick return to the streets. SEC. 3. ARMED VIOLENT CRIMINAL APPREHENSION DIRECTIVE. The Attorney General must establish an armed violent criminal apprehension program within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Each US attorney must designate a prosecutor and create a task force to remove armed violent criminals from the streets. The task force will develop strategies for removing armed violent criminals from the streets, considering the importance of severe punishment, effectiveness of laws, resources available to law enforcement agencies, and the nature of violent crime in the district. The Attorney General requires monthly reports from United States attorneys on the number of defendants charged with violating specific sections of title 18 related to violent crime. The Attorney General mandates regular reports from United States attorneys on defendants charged with violating specific sections of title 18 related to violent crime. Additionally, the Attorney General must submit a compilation of this information to Congress twice a year, along with a report on waivers granted under subsection (b) of the law. The Attorney General can waive the requirements of subsection (a) for a United States attorney upon request, following guidelines established by the Attorney General. The Attorney General considers the number of assistant United States attorneys and level of violent crime in the district when granting waivers. An armed violent criminal is defined as someone accused of violating specific sections of the United States Code. This section expires after a certain period. The section expires after a 5-year period starting 180 days after the Act's enactment, applying to individuals accused of specific violations of the United States Code. Repeal of prohibitions on semiautomatic assault weapons and large capacity ammunition feeding devices. Amendments are made to various sections of title 18, United States Code, including the removal of subsections (v) and (w) in section 922, the striking of paragraph (30) in section 921(a), and changes to section 921(a)(31)(A) and section 923(i). Additionally, section 924(a)(1)(B) is amended to remove references to subsections (r), (v), and (w). Amendments to various sections of title 18, United States Code include removing subsections (v) and (w) in section 922, striking paragraph (30) in section 921(a), and changing section 921(a)(31)(A) and section 923(i). Section 924(a)(1)(B) is also amended to remove references to subsections (r), (v), and (w). Additionally, section 110104 of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 is repealed. SEC. 5. Mandatory prison terms for possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm or destructive device during a federal crime that is a crime of violence or a drug trafficking crime. Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code is amended to include mandatory prison terms for possessing a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. The amendment to Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code mandates specific prison terms for individuals who possess, brandish, or discharge a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. The amendment to Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code imposes specific prison terms for individuals involved in a crime of violence or drug trafficking with a firearm. Possession of certain types of firearms results in additional sentencing, such as short-barreled rifles or shotguns adding 10 years, and machine guns or destructive devices adding 30 years. Subsequent convictions under this subsection lead to increased penalties. The amendment to Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code imposes specific prison terms for individuals involved in a crime of violence or drug trafficking with a firearm. Subsequent convictions result in increased penalties, including a mandatory minimum of 20 years imprisonment for possessing or brandishing a firearm during the crime. The amendment to Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code mandates specific prison terms for individuals involved in a crime of violence or drug trafficking with a firearm. Subsequent offenses result in harsher penalties, including a minimum of 25 years imprisonment for using a firearm and 30 years if a machinegun or destructive device is involved. The court mandates specific prison terms for individuals involved in a crime of violence or drug trafficking with a firearm. Subsequent offenses result in harsher penalties, including a minimum of 30 years imprisonment for using a machinegun, destructive device, firearm silencer, or firearm muffler. Probationary sentences are not allowed for such offenses, and imprisonment terms do not run concurrently with other crimes involving firearms. The subsection mandates concurrent imprisonment terms for individuals convicted of a crime involving a firearm, prohibiting release during the imposed sentence. Passed the House of Representatives on March 22, 1996. Attest: ROBIN H. CARLE, Clerk.
